nodes.label: technology standard
nodes.description: Technology standards take a more prescriptive approach by requiring a specific technology, process or product than performance standards.

nodes.label: blue hydrogen
nodes.description: Blue hydrogen is produced mainly from natural gas. The definition of blue hydrogen includes the use of carbon capture and storage (CCS) to trap and store this carbon.

nodes.label: Energy-efficient buildings
nodes.description: Energy-efficient buildings are designed to use as little energy as possible. Measures to make a building energy-efficient encompass the building’s entire lifecycle.

nodes.label: wood gas
nodes.description: Wood gas is a fuel gas that can be used for furnaces, stoves, and vehicles. It is a type of fuel gas.

nodes.label: biodiesel
nodes.description: Biodiesel is a renewable, biodegradable fuel manufactured domestically from vegetable oils, animal fats, or recycled restaurant grease.

nodes.label: regulatory instrument
nodes.description: Regulatory instruments, or "authority" in Hood and Margetts' NATO scheme, set boundaries on behaviour through rules, like emissions disclosure, fossil fuel bans, and spatial planning laws.

nodes.label: renewables
nodes.description: Renewables are a natural resource or source of energy that are not depleted by use, often with a low carbon footprint

nodes.label: Heliothermic
nodes.description: Heliothermic energy is a renewable energy source that uses mirrors to reflect sunlight and concentrate it into a receiver

nodes.label: technologies
nodes.description: Human-created methods for extending agency.

nodes.label: economic instrument
nodes.description: Economic instruments, or "treasury" in Hood and Margetts' NATO scheme, are instruments that have the power over money, taxation, and spending or influencing markets. Examples are Carbon taxes or cap-and-trade schemes.

nodes.label: Loss & Damage
nodes.description: the consequences of climate change that go beyond what people can adapt to

nodes.label: mitigation governance
nodes.description: Development and implementation of strategies, regulations, and initiatives to mitigate greenhouse gases

nodes.label: marine energy
nodes.description: Marine energy, also known as marine and hydrokinetic energy, is a renewable energy source that comes from the natural movement of water.

nodes.label: food safety standards
nodes.description: Food safety standards are a set of rules and regulations established by governments, international organizations, and industry bodies to ensure the safety and quality of the food supply chain.

nodes.label: Direct casting for iron and steel
Coke dry quenching for iron and steel
nuclear safety standard
nodes.description: These standards aim to protect human health and the environment against the dangers arising from ionising radiation. It sets limits on the maximum radiation dose that anyone should receive under normal conditions, as well as sets protective limits on the radioactivity in soil, water and air that comes from human activities.

nodes.label: electricity distribution sector
nodes.description: Sector involving the delivery of electricity from high-voltage transmission lines to end users at lower voltages through a network of local power lines and transformers

nodes.label: water quality standard
nodes.description: It regulates the quality of water bodies aiming to prevent, reduce and/or eliminate pollution. It describes the desired condition of a water body and the means by which that condition will be protected or achieved

nodes.label: electricity supply sector
nodes.description: electric power generation, transmission and distribution activities

nodes.label: Scrap preheating for iron and steel
solar energy
nodes.description: Solar energy is the radiation from the sun that can be converted into heat, electricity, or chemical reactions

nodes.label: carbon capture and storage
nodes.description: Technology that enables the capture and sequestration of carbon dioxide emissions from the atmosphere to help mitigate climate change.

nodes.label: wind energy
nodes.description: Wind energy harnesses the kinetic energy of moving air by using large wind turbines located on land (onshore) or in sea- or freshwater (offshore).

nodes.label: renewable portfolio standard
nodes.description: Renewable Portfolio Standards (RPS) require that a minimum percentage of electricity is generated from specified renewable sources.

nodes.label: afforestation
nodes.description: establishment of a forest or stand of trees in an area where there was no previous tree cover

nodes.label: environmental noise standard
nodes.description: It provides recommendations on acceptable noise levels to protect human health.

nodes.label: energy efficiency standard
nodes.description: Energy efficiency standards are government regulations that set a minimum level of energy performance for buildings or appliances, typically measured by an energy rating scale (like A-G), meaning that products or properties must meet a certain level of efficiency to be sold or rented, aiming to reduce energy consumption and carbon emissions; in practice, this often means landlords must ensure their rental properties reach a minimum energy efficiency rating.

nodes.label: offshore wind
nodes.description: Offshore wind refers to large wind turbines located in sea or freshwater locations.

nodes.label: wood fuel
nodes.description: Fuelwood is wood that is harvested from forestlands and combusted directly for useable heat in the residential and commercial sectors and power in the electric utility sector.

nodes.label: clean technology
nodes.description: Service, process, or product that enables the reduction of negative environmental impacts through significant energy efficiency improvements, the sustainable use of resources, or environmental protection activities

nodes.label: drinking water standard
nodes.description: It sets legal limits for contaminants in drinking water aiming to guarantee its safety and protect human health.

nodes.label: Solar photovoltaic
nodes.description: Solar photovoltaic is a technology that uses sunlight to generate electricity

nodes.label: building code and standard
nodes.description: The term 'building codes' refers to regulations that set out the standards to which all buildings and other structures must conform. They cover design, construction, alteration, repair and maintenance, and specify the minimum requirements necessary to safeguard the health, as well as other impacts on the environment.

nodes.label: hydroelectric energy generation
nodes.description: generation of electricity using water as a renewable energy source, including hydropower plants and tidal energy systems

nodes.label: hydrogen
nodes.description: It is a clean-burning fuel, and can produce heat and electricity with only water vapor as a by-product.  Hydrogen can be made directly from fossil fuels or biomass, or it can be produced by passing electricity through water.

nodes.label: emission standard
nodes.description: Emission standards are legal limits on the amount of pollutants that can be released into the atmosphere. They apply to vehicles, engines, and fuels.

nodes.label: Smelt reduction for iron and steel sector
wind turbines
nodes.description: Wind turbines are machines that convert the kinetic energy of wind into electricity.

nodes.label: biogasoline
nodes.description: Biogasoline is a type of gasoline that's made from biomass, such as algae, agricultural waste, or plant materials like sugarcane and beets. It's also known as renewable gasoline.

nodes.label: green hydrogen
nodes.description: Green hydrogen is made by using clean electricity from surplus renewable energy sources, such as solar or wind power, to electrolyse water.

nodes.label: adaptation
nodes.description: The process of adjusting to living in a changing climate. This can include altering behaviour, systems, and ways of life to reduce or avoid both current and future harms from climate impacts.

nodes.label: Windbreaks
nodes.description: Windbreaks are linear plantings of trees and shrubs designed to provide economic, environmental and community benefits. The primary purpose of most windbreaks is to slow the wind which creates a more beneficial condition for soils, crops, livestock, wildlife and people.

nodes.label: energy efficiency
nodes.description: Practice of improving energy consumption to perform the same task or produce the same result. Involves implementing strategies, technologies, and behaviours that optimise energy use without compromising output quality, comfort, or productivity

nodes.label: reforestation
nodes.description: natural or intentional restocking of existing forests and woodlands that have been depleted

nodes.label: energy supply sector
nodes.description: The activities of industries involved in the production, distribution, and sale of energy, including electricity, gas, and renewables.

nodes.label: carbon dioxide
nodes.description: Chemical compound and greenhouse gas that comes from the extraction and burning of fossil fuels (e.g. coal, oil, and natural gas), from wildfires, and natural processes like volcanic eruptions. It is made up of one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms.

nodes.label: air pollution standard
nodes.description: There are national or regional policies setting limit values to the concentration of different pollutants in the air to protect the public health and the environment.

nodes.label: zero-carbon smelting
nodes.description: Eliminates all direct GHGs from the traditional aluminium smelting process, instead producing oxygen

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 7
nodes.description: SDG7: affordable and clean energy

nodes.label: sustainable development goals
nodes.description: 17 goals adopted by all countries in the United Nations in 2015 to be achieved by 2030

nodes.label: wind farms
nodes.description: A wind farm is a group of wind turbines in the same location used to produce electricity.

nodes.label: hydropower
nodes.description: Hydropower is the use of falling or fast-running water to produce electricity or to power machines.

nodes.label: electric power production
nodes.description: process of generating electricity from various energy sources, such as fossil fuels, nuclear power, and renewables

nodes.label: hydrogen infrastructure
nodes.description: The infrastructure required for the production, transportation and usage of hydrogen, including hydrogen pipeline transport, points of hydrogen production and hydrogen stations.

nodes.label: mitigation
nodes.description: Reducing the emission of and quantity of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. This involves cutting emissions from "sources" of greenhouse gases e.g. petrol cars and enhancing "sinks" which draw emissions down from the atmosphere e.g. forests.

nodes.label: fossil fuel
nodes.description: Fossil fuel is a generic term for non-renewable energy sources such as coal, fossil gas, crude oil, and petroleum products. Fossil fuels are carbon-based and release carbon into the atmosphere when burned.

nodes.label: environmental standard
nodes.description: Environmental standards are legal tools used by governments to limit pollution and enforce climate action. They set thresholds for air, water, emissions, and waste, ensuring industries comply. Examples include air quality limits, emissions caps, and energy efficiency rules, promoting sustainability.

nodes.label: feed-in-tariff
nodes.description: A policy instrument designed to support the development and acceleration of renewable energy sources by providing a guaranteed, above-market price for producers.

nodes.label: active labour market policies
nodes.description: Government programmes that intervene in the labour market to help the unemployed find work, but also for the underemployed and employees looking for better jobs.

nodes.label: hazardous pesticide standard
nodes.description: It proposes guidelines, recommendations, and regulations aimed at ensuring the safe and effective use of pesticides. These standards help protect human health, the environment, and ensure food safety.

nodes.label: greenhouse gas
nodes.description: Greenhouse gases are molecules in our atmosphere that absorb heat radiating from Earth’s surface, preventing it from being emitted into space.

nodes.label: coal
nodes.description: Coal is a combustible black or brownish-black sedimentary rock with a high amount of carbon and hydrocarbons. It is a non-renewable energy source and fossil fuel, and has four main types.

nodes.label: just transition
nodes.description: Broadly defined as ensuring that no one is left behind or pushed behind in the transition to low-carbon.

nodes.label: feed-in-premium
nodes.description: Under a feed-in premium (FIP) scheme, electricity from renewable energy sources (RES) is typically sold on the electricity spot market and RES producers receive a premium on top of the market price of their electricity production.

nodes.label: waste management standard
nodes.description: They are policies to improve the way businesses and/or households sort their waste, optimising the waste collection and recycling.

nodes.label: Onshore wind
nodes.description: onshore wind refers to large wind turbines located on land.

nodes.label: codes and standards
nodes.description: Codes and standards are regulatory instruments that specify minimum standards to protect health and safety. This ranges from performance standards, which prescribe outcomes while allowing flexibility to achieve compliance, to the more prescriptive approach of technology-specific standards.

nodes.label: standard for soil quality
nodes.description: Soil quality standards are guidelines that protect and improve the health of soil. They are important for agriculture, biodiversity, and carbon sequestration.
